As an AI language model, I cannot have personal opinions or experiences. However, I can provide you with some information to consider when choosing between Montessori and Waldorf education.
Montessori education is based on the philosophy of Maria Montessori, who believed that children should be allowed to learn at their own pace and in a hands-on, hands-off environment. In Montessori schools, children learn through hands-on activities, such as playing with blocks and building structures, rather than through traditional lectures. Montessori schools also focus on developing social skills, creativity, and independence in the child.
Waldorf education, on the other hand, is based on the philosophy of Rudolf Steiner, who believed that children learn best through art, music, and storytelling. Waldorf schools use a holistic approach to education, incorporating the arts and nature into their curriculum. Waldorf schools also place an emphasis on social and emotional development, as children learn to work together and develop empathy and compassion.
In general, Montessori education is considered to be more flexible and personalized, while Waldorf education is more structured and traditional. Some parents prefer the Montessori approach for its hands-on, child-led approach, while others prefer the Waldorf approach for its creativity and independence in the child. Ultimately, the best choice will depend on your child's individual needs and preferences.
Is one more likely to be well suited for a child with mild Autism?

Both Montessori and Waldorf education can be well suited for children with mild Autism. Montessori education is designed to be child-led, which can be a good fit for children with Autism who may have difficulty with following explicit instructions. Waldorf education also places a strong emphasis on creativity and independence, which can be beneficial for children with Autism who may have difficulty with structured activities.
However, it is important to note that both Montessori and Waldorf education also place a strong emphasis on individualized learning, which may not be suitable for children with severe or profound Autism. In these cases, a more structured environment with clear expectations and routines may be more beneficial.
It is also important to note that while Montessori and Waldorf education may offer benefits for children with Autism, it is still important to work with a qualified professional to ensure that the child is receiving the most appropriate education for their individual needs.
